awd_titl_txt: CREST Center for Interface Design and Engineered Assembly of Low-Dimensional Systems (IDEALS)
awd_abstract_narration:
Center for Interface Design and Engineered Assembly of Low-Dimensional Systems (IDEALS)

With National Science Foundation support, CUNY City College, will establish the Center for Interface Design and Engineered Assembly of Low-dimensional Systems (IDEALS).  The Center will address the national need for accelerating the pace of discovery and deployment of advanced materials to address critical needs and grand challenges, such as clean energy, national security, and human welfare. The goal of the Center is to design and discover materials with new and enhanced functionalities to further technology, energy and health applications.  

Twenty two researchers from Chemistry, Physics, and Chemical, Biomedical and Electrical Engineering departments from partner institutions will employ experimental, analytical and numerical modelling tools to design and discover complex novel materials with new and enhanced functionalities, and integrate education and research to enhance both enterprises within the Center. Along with the research goals, the Center will enhance the educational experience of students, and use proven and innovative approaches to recruit and retain students from underrepresented groups in order to produce a diverse workforce of materials science and engineering leaders trained for careers in academia or industry, including high-tech manufacturing jobs.  

Center research efforts are organized into three interdisciplinary and cross-pollinating subprojects: (1) Low-Dimensional Functional Materials and Nano-Heterostructures (2) Bio-inspired Re-Configurable Materials; and (3) Novel Materials Probes and Design Formalism. Synergy among the three subprojects stems from their thematic overlap and complementarity. Similarities in approaches of material synthesis, characterization and theoretical/computational methods also serve to ensure that links will be forged, leading to new discoveries. 

Two frontier materials systems will be investigated in the Center: crystalline layered materials and engineered superlattices and aggregated bio-molecular or hybrid materials. A suite of sophisticated tools and theoretical approaches will be developed and deployed to investigate the materials and explore their functionality and potential applications in areas as diverse as energy generation, sensing, quantum computing, and medical diagnosis and treatment of cancer.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: RESEARCH FOUNDATION OF THE CITY UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The CREST Center for Interface Design and Engineered Assembly of Low-dimensional Systems or IDEALS-I was launched on April 1, 2016. The award was for $5M for a duration of 5 years. It was followed by 2 years of no cost extensions (NCE). Twenty one faculty members in Chemistry, Physics, Chemical Engineering and Electrical Engineering were involved in the research and mentoring efforts. A multi-institutional program, it was centered at The City College of New York and included researchers from Lehman College, the CUNY Advanced Science Research Center, the University of Puerto Rico, Mayaguez and Virginia Tech. (Fig. 1)

 

IDEALS-I had a considerable impact in advancing the state of the art in materials science and nanomaterials, elevating the institutional research standing, and forging productive collaborations among CREST participants and beyond. The research was organized into three inter-connected research thrusts or Subprojects supported by an education and outreach platform meant to enhance the research experience. (Fig. 2) IDEALS-I instituted a host of interventions aimed at pursuing overarching Research and Education goals, and establishing a thriving and diverse STEM community through extensive recruitment and enrichment of students' experience. Some of these activities included co-mentoring of doctoral students by at least two faculty mentors, a "tools of the trade" course on nanoscience and nanotechnology for all students, a Graduate Student Support Network, and a summer Research Experience for Undergraduate (REU) program.  Our efforts resulted in an inclusive and sustainable research community that is poised to carry out the ambitious research program of the current IDEALS Phase II award, and to become a model for diversity in STEM.

 

Intellectual merit

Cutting-edge advances in nanoscience and materials research: The IDEALS-I program aimed to "discover materials with new and enhanced functionalities that stem from the unique properties of interfaces and self-assembly." Important key advances were obtained in (a) modification of topological insulator (TI) materials to amplify their potentially transformative properties, (b) growth of TI nanostructures and multilayers by MBE (c) II-VI semiconductor based intersubband devices, (d) CdSe ultra-small QDs for photovoltaics, (d) novel self-assembled materials for light harvesting applications,  (e) functionalized Janus nanoparticles as "nanomotors" that respond to external stimuli,  (f) self-assembled biomaterials for energy and light harvesting, (f) physics and applications of N-V centers in diamond,  (g) defects in hBN as single photon emitters,  (h) modeling and prediction of novel quantum phenomena,  (i) physics and applications of SERS, modification of perovskite nanoparticles for medical applications, and other areas. The research activity resulted in over 200 publications in leading journals and more than 300 presentations at national and international conferences. (Fig. 3)

 

Broader impacts

An inclusive and diverse STEM community:  The Center supported and provided research opportunities to 29 doctoral students of which 12 are from underrepresented minority (URM) groups and 8 are female. Twenty one (21) have already completed their PhD's and have entered the workforce in industry or academia. (Fig. 4) It also supported over 15 undergraduates during the academic years and provided partial support for 13 postdoctoral fellows (23% URM). The program built an REU program that engaged a highly diverse student population, and served as a recruitment pathway to the doctoral programs in CUNY. Seventy three (73) undergraduates from a host of institutions across the nation participated in the summer REU program [78% URM (53% H, 25% AA] and 53% female). (Fig. 5) The last two years, REU participant numbers were increased by the support from an REU Site (IDMinNYC) that was established in 2020 by two IDEALS faculty.  Overall, the participation of students from URM groups within IDEALS is significantly greater than the CUNY-wide and national numbers. For example, of the 25 PhD students supported through the IDEALS program, 40% are from URM groups, and 30% are female, far exceeding the CUNY Graduate Center (GC) numbers in Chemistry and Physics of ~8% URM and ~20% female. A striking 78% of our REU students are from URM groups and 53% are female.

 

Transformative institutional changes: IDEALS-I spearheaded a transformative shift in doctoral admissions in the doctoral program in Chemistry at the CUNY GC, during which the percentage of doctoral student applicants from URM groups nearly doubled, from 8.7% in 2015 to 15% in 2020. The percentage of accepted students from these groups grew from about 2-3% before 2016 to 11% in 2020. IDEALS students received innovative interdisciplinary research training by working with multiple faculty mentors and conducting research across disciplines. IDEALS participated in the creation of a Master's program in Nanoscience at the CUNY Graduate Center, and a Photonics Track in the Physics Doctoral program. IDEALS faculty leveraged the Center's resources to attract more than $25M in new external grants. The faculty organized conferences and symposia such as the Colloids Gordon Conference, the North American Conference on MBE, MRS Spring Meeting Symposia, and Graphene NY.


Last Modified: 07/24/2023
Modified by: Maria C Tamargo
